questions.question: What is splat.top?
questions.answer: splat.top is a website that tracks the Top 500 players in Splatoon 3 as reported by SplatNet3. The website also provides a history for each player's entire Top 500 journey and analytics on the state of the game via the Top 500. For more details, visit our GitHub repository.

questions.question: Why can't I find myself?
questions.answer:
If you can't find yourself in the history, there's two possible reasons:

  • Just entered the Top 500: The system updates every 10 minutes, so if you've just entered the Top 500, your history may not be immediately available.
  • Brief appearance: If you were in the Top 500 for a short time, you may not find your history.

questions.question: How often are the rankings updated?
questions.answer:
• February 2023-August 2023: Data was updated hourly. Special thanks to splatoon3.ink for providing the data.
  • August 2023-March 2024: Updates occurred every fifteen minutes.
  • March 2024-present: Data is now updated every ten minutes.

questions.question: Can I see my own ranking?
questions.answer: Yes, you can view your ranking if you've been in the Top 500. Search using any in-game name you had when you reached the Top 500. Alternatively, if you have your NPLN ID you can access your page directly via splat.top/player/npln_id_goes_here. Note: If you were briefly in the Top 500 and missed by our data collection, you won't find your ranking.

questions.question: My weapon data is incorrect. Can you fix it?
questions.answer: Weapon data is calculated based on the snapshot appearances in the Top 500 as maintained by SplatNet3. While the methodology tends to be more accurate than not, there are edge cases where the weapon data may be incorrect. This is not something we can fix without massive effort, as it would require at least doubling the scraping cadence to minimize errors. If you believe the data is incorrect, feel free to contact us with the details. We can't guarantee a fix, but the knowledge helps us improve the system for everyone.

questions.question: Can I have access to the data? I want to analyze it myself.
questions.answer:
Access to the full dataset is limited. Request access by contacting us with your intended use. Contributions to splat.top or the Splatoon community are key criteria for access. Being a top player or content creator is not enough.

For students: Academic projects can receive an anonymized data subset. Contact us on Discord or Twitter with project details.

questions.question: I own a website and I want to use your data. Can I?
questions.answer: We may provide an API endpoint for your data needs. Contact us on Discord, Twitter, or via a GitHub issue on our GitHub repository. Pull requests greatly increase the chance of support.

questions.question: I'm a content creator and I want to feature your website. Can I?
questions.answer: Yes, using data or analytics from splat.top is fine as long as you credit the website. We appreciate a mention or link to the site. If you'd like to collaborate, have a special data request, or would just like the analytics explained in more detail for a younger audience, contact us.

questions.question: The line cuts off randomly, what happened?
questions.answer: It's probably a data outage caused by Nintendo. The scraper is designed to be highly robust, but it can't handle every situation. There are times when the data is simply not available. We try our best to make sure the data pipeline is uninterrupted, but sometimes Nintendo's decisions are out of our control. We apologize for the inconvenience.

analytics.skill_offset.graph_subtitle: Skill Offset is a correlation, not a cause.
analytics.skill_offset.xaxis.title: Appearance Count (Top 500)
analytics.skill_offset.yaxis.title: Skill Offset
analytics.skill_offset.tooltip: Skill Offset is a measure of how well a weapon performs in the Top 500 as compared to the expected value at that appearance rate. A positive skill offset indicates that the weapon and/or the players using it are performing better than expected. A negative skill offset indicates the opposite. A weapon with a high pick rate and low skill offset indicates that the weapon is carrying players to the Top 500. A weapon with a low pick rate and high skill offset indicates that the weapon is being used by a few highly skilled players. Data here will change frequently as the Top 500 weapon picks will update even if the player isn't playing X Battles. Use this information with caution. Future updates will include time lag and other factors to reduce the influence of these changes.
analytics.skill_offset.controller.title: Controls
analytics.skill_offset.controller.linlog.label: X Axis Scale
analytics.lorenz.graph_subtitle: The Lorenz Curve and Gini Coefficient together represent the health of the meta.
analytics.lorenz.xaxis.title: Weapon
analytics.lorenz.yaxis.title: Share of X Power
analytics.lorenz.marker.format:
{point.name}
Cumulative Share of X Power: {point.y_percent:.2f}%
Share of X Power: {point.diff:.2f}%
analytics.lorenz.tooltip: The Lorenz Curve is a graphical representation of wealth distribution. In this case, it represents the distribution of X Power in the Top 500. The Gini Coefficient is a measure of inequality and shows the health of the meta by indicating how evenly distributed weapons are in their success. A Gini Coefficient of 0 represents perfect equality, meaning all weapons are equally successful, indicating a perfectly balanced meta. Conversely, a Gini Coefficient of 1 represents perfect inequality, where one weapon dominates entirely, indicating a highly imbalanced meta.
analytics.lorenz.marker.label: Lorenz Curve
analytics.lorenz.gini.title: Meta Health
